Employment: Job Network (Question No. 2096) Mr Brendan O’Connor asked the Minister for Employment Services, upon notice, on 25 June 2003: (1) In the electoral division of Burke, how many Job Network offices were there at the start of (a) 2001, (b) 2002, and (c) 2003. (2) Does he know if any Job Network offices will be closing before the end of the year 2003; if so, which ones. (1) In the electoral division of Burke there were: (a) Start 2001: 14 sites comprised of 2 full Job Network services and 12 other sites which were part services only or outreach. This included three New Enterprise Incentive Scheme sites, (b) Start 2002: as above, (c) start 2003: 14 sites comprising 3 full Job Network services and 11 other sites which were part service only or outreach. This included three New Enterprise Incentive Scheme sites. (2) In the electoral division of Burke, a total of 3 Job Network offices closed as part of the transition to the new contract. These offices were located at Kyneton, Melton and Bacchus Marsh. They were replaced by new providers under the new contract. As a result of the Employment Services Contract3 (ESC3), as at 1 July 2003, there are now 15 offices comprising Job Network, Job Placement and New Enterprise Incentive Scheme, located at Kyneton, Sunbury, Bacchus Marsh, Monegeetta, Melton, Melton South and Deer Park. (2) Have any actions been taken in the Human Rights Commission against DasFleet by any of its employees or former employees in each of the last four financial years, including the current financial year; if so, for each instance (a) on what basis was the case initiated, (b) what has been the cost of defending the case to date, and (c) did it involve claims of harassment, discrimination or both. (3) Were a number of Victorian drivers refused supply of new shoes on presentation of vouchers for the purchase of such shoes over the course of the past twelve months; if so, (a) why were the vouchers not honoured by the retailer, (b) how many drivers were embarrassed by the vouchers not being honoured, and (c) has DasFleet apologised to the drivers in question; if not, why not. ourable member’s question: The Special Minister of State has no portfolio responsibility for any organization named “DasFleet”. Health: Therapeutic Goods Administration (Question No. 2102) Mr Murphy asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 26 June 2003: (1) Is the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) required to cover its operating costs entirely from the licence, inspection and registration fees it charges. (2) Is it the case that the TGA compliance branch employs only 11 auditors nationally; if not, (a) how many does it employ, and (b) does the TGA propose to increase that number. (3) Is the TGA compliance branch well behind in its audit program; if so, (a) how far behind is the TGA in its audit program, and (b) does this leave open the possibility of further manufacturing standard failures as recently experienced with Pan Pharmaceuticals; if not, why not.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Brough
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Abbott
theText: The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the hon(4) Has the delay in the audit program been exacerbated by the adoption in August 2002 of a new industry code of practice requiring a longer audit process; if so, has the TGA received additional resources to allow it to administer the new code and, if it has not, why not. (5) How quickly is the TGA responding to manufacturers’ replies to audit reports. the honourable member’s question: (1) Since the 1998-1999 financial year, the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) has been a full cost recovery agency for all activities that fall within the scope of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989. This includes regulation of the therapeutic goods industry, the TGA’s public health responsibilities, the provision of information to consumers and TGA’s support for industry generally (ie. facilitation of exports and international harmonisation of standards). The fees and charges levied by the TGA include those for the listing and registration of therapeutic goods on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods (ARTG), as well as the audit and licensing of Australian manufacturers and certification of overseas manufacturers wishing to supply therapeutic goods in Australia. (2) (a) and (b) The TGA has an auditor pool of 44 officers, comprising fourteen (14) lead quality systems auditors and thirty (30) technical specialists to carry out audits of manufacturers of therapeutic goods supplied in Australia. Lead auditors are located in the Manufacturer Assessment Section of the Office of Devices, Blood and Tissues of the TGA in Canberra, Melbourne and Sydney. The TGA no longer has a Compliance Branch. Technical specialists are utilised where additional expertise is required at a particular audit. This expertise covers areas such as analytical chemistry, microbiology/virology, biotechnology, biomaterials, engineering and computer systems. The TGA, in recognising the need to maintain an effective strategy of scheduling audits according to risk, is in the process of recruiting an additional four (4) lead auditors and training an additional eleven (11) specialist auditors. In addition, non-auditing staff are being recruited to carry out the assessment of evidence for overseas manufacturers wishing to supply therapeutic goods to Australia, thus relieving lead auditors of this task and allowing them to focus on auditing alone. (3) (a) & (b) The TGA audit schedule is drawn up annually based upon manufacturer risk assessment and the available resources. At this stage the TGA has completed 41 per cent of audits of Australian and overseas manufacturers included on the 2003 schedule. It is expected the program will be satisfactorily completed with the engagement of the additional resources envisaged in (2) above. The risk management approach to the scheduling of audits gives high priority to auditing those manufacturers with a high-risk profile. The risk factors taken into account include: type of products manufactured; results of previous Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) audit; significant changes within the company, eg changes to key personnel, building, equipment or products; adverse medicine reaction reports, medicine problem reports and device incident reports; results of TGA Laboratories testing of random or targeted samples of products; recalls of products not meeting safety and /or quality standards; information from other agencies; and post-licensing surveillance investigations.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Andrews
theText: The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer toThe TGA uses the above information when scheduling audits and selects the most appropriate audit strategy, which may include an unscheduled audit. This approach is designed to more readily detect failures in compliance with manufacturing standards. The TGA’s risk management audit strategy has been recognised as world leading by international organisations. (4) The content and principles of the Australian Code of GMP for Medicinal Products (August 2002) are very similar to the previous Australian Code of GMP for Medicinal Products (1990) other than for two additional requirements relating to marketing authorisation. These additional provisions require auditors to check that the product formulation matches that registered/listed with the TGA and that manufacturers validate their manufacturing and analytical processes and procedures. Although these are new requirements, they were always investigated during TGA audits under the old Code of GMP because of their importance in assuring product quality. Consequently, there has been no significant change to the length of the audit process and no adverse impact on audit waiting times or resourcing requirements. (5) The TGA has maintained its usual standard operating procedure approach of responding within a target time frame of one month to manufacturers' replies to audit reports. There has not been an increase in target time in the last ten years. Education: Higher Education Contribution Scheme Contributions (Question No. 2109) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 26 June 2003: (1) Has he seen an article by Professor Peter Karmel from the Australian National University titled “Student contribution bigger than predicted” published in The Australian on 18 June 2003. (2) Is it the case that the average student share of the cost of HECS-liable courses in 2005 is expected to be almost 40 per cent – a great deal higher than the 26.8 per cent described as the average student contribution towards the cost of their education on page 21 of the ministerial statement Our Universities – Backing Australia’s Future. (3) Is there a higher average student cost burden in any other OECD country in respect of publicly funded higher education institutions; if so, which countries and what are the average student burdens in each country. (1) Yes. (2) No. The 40 per cent figure used by Professor Karmel does not appear to take into account the Commonwealth subsidies involved in HECS. To calculate the average actual student contribution, the following subsidies need to be taken into account: 25% discount for upfront payers; 15% bonus for voluntary repayments; debt write downs due to death of the debtor; remission of HECS debts in special circumstances; and provision for doubtful debt. On this basis, the Department of Education, Science and Training (DEST) has estimated the average actual student contribution to be 26.8 per cent in 2005 of total Commonwealth funding to universities. (3) DEST has advised that there is no strictly comparable data available on the average student cost burden across OECD countries of which we are aware.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Dr Nelson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Health: D3/Lipidiol (Question No. 2123) Ms George asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 26 June 2003: (1) In what year and under what guidelines did the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) give approval for the use of vitamin D3/Lipidiol in trials for the treatment of liver cancer. (2) Which body authorises the trials of vitamin D3/Lipidiol for the treatment of liver cancer in Australian hospitals and which hospitals are currently involved in trials of vitamin D3/Lipidiol for liver cancer treatment. (3) Is there an obligation for such trials to comply with guidelines established by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC); if not, why not; if so, who is responsible for ensuring compliance with these guidelines. (4) Is there a regime of full disclosure of potential side effects and risks involved in patient participation in the trials of vitamin D3/Lipidiol treatment for liver cancer; if so, who is responsible for such disclosure to patients. (5) Is it conceivable that a patient could be part of a trial of vitamin D3/Lipidiol even though they had failed to meet all the specific selection criteria for the trial; if so, who would be held responsible for such a situation. (6) Do protocols exist for the monitoring and evaluation of the trials of vitamin D3/Lipidiol in the treatment of liver cancer; if so, (a) who determines the protocols; (b) where can they be accessed, and (c) are such protocols standard throughout the hospital system. (7) What avenues are open to the families of patients involved in trials should they wish to pursue specific concerns and complaints and which body is responsible for dealing with such concerns and complaints. (8) If the TGA authorised the use of vitamin D3/Lipidiol in trials for the treatment of liver cancer, is it in a position to provide some public assessment of the efficacy of these trials; if so, what is that assessment; if not, why not. the honourable member’s question: (1) Trials for the use of vitamin D3 in the treatment of liver cancer were notified to the TGA via the Clinical Trial Notification (CTN) Scheme in 1998 and 2002. Under the CTN Scheme TGA approval is not required for a trial to commence. (2) There are two systems for clinical trials using unapproved medicines in Australia. The liver trials were notified to the TGA under the CTN Scheme, whereby a trial is reviewed by a Human Research Ethics Committee (HREC) and certain undertakings about compliance with international Good Clinical Practice (GCP) and the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) National Statement on Ethical Conduct of Research Involving Humans are obtained from the institution, the investigator, the trial sponsor and the HREC. Under the CTN Scheme the HREC is the authorising body. There is an alternate approval system based on TGA review of summary data, which is rarely used. Only one hospital is currently involved in trials as discussed in (1), but the identity of the hospital would be regarded as commercial-in-confidence. (3) Yes. This is required as a condition of the exemption that allows the trial to use an unregistered good. The HREC is obliged to monitor this and the TGA has the power to seek information and to inspect sites to monitor that this is happening.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Andrews
theText: The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to(4) It is a requirement under both the NHMRC National Statement and the Good Clinical Practice guidelines, that apply to all clinical trials operating under the therapeutic goods legislation, that all clinical trial subjects provide fully informed consent. The process of obtaining this should involve a full discussion of the potential risks and benefits of the treatment. Patient information forms are also usually provided. Consent information and documentation would be reviewed by the HREC as part of its approval and consent is usually obtained from subjects by the investigator. (5) The protocol that is approved by the HREC outlines the inclusion and exclusion criteria that must apply for the trial. Enrolment of patients outside these criteria should not occur. In the unlikely event this occurred, the recruiting investigator would be responsible for notifying the HREC and sponsor. (6) In order to comply with compulsory Good Clinical Practice guidelines and the NHMRC National Statement, any trials for the treatment of liver cancer should have a protocol that would include information on monitoring and evaluation. (a) Protocols are assessed for their adequacy as part of the HREC review. (b) While sometimes they may be provided to the public by the sponsor on request, they are regarded as commercial-in-confidence by many sponsors. (c) There are common features relating to all protocols in terms of the need to define inclusion and exclusion criteria, treatment dosage and duration, monitoring of subjects, etc, but actual protocols differ depending on the particular circumstances of the trial. For example; the nature of the condition and the treatment under investigation. (7) Patients are given contact details of relevant trial personnel, usually the investigator and a local contact officer, when they are recruited into a trial. If they or their families have any concerns, these individuals are usually the first point of contact. The trial’s investigators are required to deal with any concerns or complaints. Other points of contact would be the institution, the sponsor, the HREC, the NHMRC and the TGA. (8) As these trials were conducted via the CTN scheme, no TGA “authorisation” was involved. As explained above, the TGA was only “notified” of the trials. There is no requirement for the TGA to be provided with the trial results, unless they form part of a registration dossier in the future. The HREC, however, should receive information on trial progress and results, as part of its monitoring. Iraq (Question No. 2129) Mr Rudd asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 26 June 2003: (1) Can he advise precisely which articles Australia is bound by under international law as an Occupying Power in Iraq. (2) Can he explain the system that the Government has put in place to ensure that Australia’s international obligations under the Geneva Convention are being met, including (a) who oversees that system, (b) who is physically making that assessment across Iraq, (c) where is that person or persons located and how often are they reporting, and (d) how many staff are working on that program. (3) What is the Government’s assessment (including that of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade) of Australia’s success as an Occupying Power at ensuring the maintenance of law and order, health and medical facilities, and education. (4) Does that assessment show that there areas for improvement; if so, what are the details. (5) Can he advise what action Australia has undertaken with the other Occupying Powers to ensure that areas of non-performance are addressed. (6) Can he advise what are the international legal sanctions that Australia would face if it does not discharge its duties as an Occupying Power effectively. (7) How many Occupying Powers are there now in Iraq. (8) Will he explain how the relationship between the Occupying Powers and the transitional authority established to discharge the responsibilities of the Occupying Powers works, both procedurally and on what legal basis there is for this relationship. (9) Is Australia an equal power under international law in this transitional authority. (10) How is the transitional authority structured, in particular, (a) where do Australian officials fit within this structure, (b) what is their role within this structure, and (c) what responsibilities are they discharging on behalf of Australia. (11) Can he advise whether a timeline is envisaged, either by the transitional authority or by the Australian Government, for an act of political self-determination to be expressed by the Iraqi people and what Australia is doing to facilitate this. (12) What is the total number estimated by (1) the USA and (2) the UK of (a) Iraqi and (b) Coalition (i) military and (ii) civilian fatalities arising from the Iraq conflict. (13) Are these estimates publicly available; if not, why not. (14) Is he able to say how many seriously injured people are in Iraqi hospitals; if not, why not. (15) Is he or his department aware of concerns expressed by international NGO’s about the health and medical situation in Iraqi hospitals; if so, is he able to say whether assessments made by those international NGOs are reliable. (16) Can he indicate what chemical weapons have been located in Iraq. (17) Can he advise whether weapons inspectors have discovered chemical munitions, anthrax, bacterial growth media or VX nerve agent in Iraq. (18) Can he indicate what biological weapons have been located in Iraq. (19) Does he stand by his statement on 4 November 2002 that “...we know Iraq is still producing chemical and biological weapons, and has endeavoured to produce nuclear weapons”; if not, why not. (20) Can he advise whether there was any doubt expressed by the intelligence community in regards to Iraq’s Weapons’ of Mass Destruction (WMD) capability. (21) Can he advise whether his department expressed any doubts to him or other members of the Government, or had any reservations regarding, allegations of Iraq’s possession of WMD. (22) What is the cost borne by the Government to send Australian weapons inspectors to Iraq to participate in searches for Iraqi WMD. (23) How does this cost compare to the financial cost for Australia of the return of UNMOVIC and IAEA weapons inspectors to Iraq. (24) Has he or his department had discussions with the US Government on the possibility of returning UN weapons inspectors to Iraq; if so, did he argue for the recommitment of UN weapons inspectors to Iraq. (25) Has he had discussions with the Government of the United Kingdom on the possibility of returning UN weapons inspectors to Iraq; if so, did he argue for the recommitment of UN weapons inspectors to Iraq. (1) Australia is one member of a coalition of countries contributing human and other resources to the Coalition Provisional Authority (CPA) presently in occupation of Iraq. In United Nations Security Council Resolution (UNSCR) 1483 of 22 May 2003, only the United States of America and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland are named as Occupying Powers.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Downer
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows :Accordingly, these States have specific and special responsibilities and obligations under UNSCR 1483, the Geneva Conventions and the Hague Regulations. Australia is not named as an Occupying Power and thus does not bear the full burden of meeting these obligations. (2) The Government established a legal watch group comprising the General Counsel (International Law), Office of International Law in the Attorney-General’s Department, the Senior Legal Adviser of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and the Director-General of the Defence Legal Service, as well as experts in international law drawn from each of those Departments. The legal watch group advises on legal matters of relevance to Australia’s participation in the Coalition Provisional Authority (CPA). The group consults with its counterparts in the governments of the Occupying Powers in Iraq, namely the United States of America and the United Kingdom, to ensure that Australia’s international legal obligations are taken into account. In addition, Australia has assigned an experienced military lawyer to the Office of General Counsel in the CPA in Baghdad. The Australian Representative Office in Baghdad also conveys Australian views on legal and other matters directly to the CPA, and maintains regular contact with Australia’s representative in the CPA Office of General Counsel. Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel in Iraq are subject to Rules of Engagement which require compliance with applicable domestic and international law regarding their presence in Iraq. ADF members have received training in applicable law and Rules of Engagement as part of their force preparation prior to deployment. The Rules of Engagement are military orders enforced through the military chain of command. Other Australian officials in Iraq in an official capacity are issued with a booklet entitled “Operational Guidelines addressed to Australian Personnel Working in Post-Conflict Iraq”. The guidelines are designed to ensure that Australian personnel do not do anything that would violate Australia’s international obligations, or that might attract criminal responsibility under Australia’s Criminal Code. (3) Australia is not named as an Occupying Power in UN Security Council Resolution 1483 and thus does not bear the full burden of meeting the obligations of the Occupying Powers. Australia is, however, making a significant contribution to the efforts of a broad coalition of countries contributing to Iraq’s rehabilitation, focusing our assistance in the field of agriculture. The assistance that Australia has provided to help meet these needs is summarised in Table A. Table A: Australian humanitarian and reconstruction assistance (detailed breakdown) Recipient Amount (AUD) Initial Commitment UN Central Emergency Revolving Fund 6,000,000 ICRC 2,000,000 Australian NGOs, including CARE Australia and Australian Red Cross 2,000,000 Additional programs, personnel 2,000,000 Sub-Total 17,500,00 0 UN Flash Appeal Commitment 0 ICRC – water, sanitation, health, protection 7,500,000 UN agencies responsible for coordinating humanitarian activities and logistical 5,500,000 arrangements Recipient Amount (AUD) WFP – food distribution 3,000,000 WHO – disease prevention, water treatment 3,000,000 UN Mine Action Service 1,500,000 CARE Australia principally in the areas of water and sanitation and mine awareness 3,000,000 programs World Vision Australia principally in the areas of water and sanitation and 1,200,000 environmental health in primary schools Save the Children Australia support to eight paediatric hospitals across Iraq 800,000 Sub-Total 38,000,00 0 Other Humanitarian and Reconstruction Priorities Revitalise Iraq’s agriculture sector 40,000,00 0 Economic Policy, Water Supply and Sanitation 5,000,000 00 (4) and (5) While emergency and reconstruction needs are progressively being identified and addressed by the Coalition, Iraqi counterparts and international organisations, rehabilitation efforts are being hampered by ongoing security concerns, including targeted sabotage of infrastructure by supporters of the former regime. Significantly degraded infrastructure and chronic problems will also take time to address. Needs assessments are being undertaken by the CPA, United Nations and International Financial Institutions, which will provide a comprehensive picture of requirements for further assistance. These assessments will be finalised for presentation at the donors’ conference to be held in Madrid on 24 October 2003. Australia is maintaining an active dialogue on rehabilitation issues with CPA officials in Baghdad, and with the United States, the United Kingdom, UN agencies, and the International Financial Institutions. (6) As explained in the answer to question one, Australia is not named as an Occupying Power in Iraq in UN Security Council Resolution 1483. (7) See answer to question one. (8) The CPA is the entity established to discharge the obligations of the Occupying Powers in Iraq and to enable the participation of other States in the interim administration and development of Iraq, as well as the provision of humanitarian and technical assistance. The status of the CPA is supported by UN Security Council Resolution 1483 and is consistent with international law relating to the roles and responsibilities of an Occupying Power. (9) No. See also answer to question one. (10) See organisation chart on the following internet site: http://www.cpa-iraq.org/CPAorgchart.pdf. (a) 14 Australian experts are currently seconded to the CPA. They are working in the following fields: Agriculture Economic policy Water and sanitation Trade Oil policy General Counsel Coalition coordination arrangements Baghdad and South Central Regions (b) Australians are involved, inter alia, in: rehabilitating the agriculture sector and development of appropriate agriculture policy the 2003 and 2004 budget processes establishing a new salary structure for civil servants and implementing of salary payments to Iraqi civil servants water and sanitation issues, including the re-establishment of the responsible Ministry assisting the Ministry of Oil in dealing with a range of practical challenges in rehabilitating this sector working with the CPA Office of General Counsel on legal issues establishing the Council for International Coordination, which is the CPA’s main mechanism for coordinating among contributing countries, and with UN and other agencies involved in Iraq’s rehabilitation helping to manage Baghdad and regional areas. The CPA has obligations under the Geneva Convention and Hague Regulations to ensure the security and humanitarian needs of the Iraqi people following the conflict. Australia has made a strong commitment to Iraq’s rehabilitation. See also answers (a) and (b) above. (11) The Iraqi Governing Council was established on 13 July 2003. This is a significant step towards establishing a democratic Iraqi Government. The next stage will entail a process to develop a new constitution. The final stage will be the election of a sovereign Iraqi Government by the Iraqi people. The exact timeline for this process is a matter for the Iraqi Governing Council to determine. Refer also to the answers to questions three and ten. (12) and (13) The Government has not received such estimates of coalition or Iraqi fatalities. (14) The Government does not have such information. (15) See also the answer to question three. There are approximately 100 NGOs currently working in Iraq, a significant number of which are working in the health sector. The Government is not in a position to comment on the reliability of the assessments of all of these NGOs. However, AusAID is working with key UN agencies, including UNICEF and WHO, and the major international NGOs, namely CARE, International Committee of the Red Cross, Save the Children and World Vision which are implementing vital reconstruction activities in the health sector. AusAID has provided assistance to a number of these organisations to respond to health needs, as detailed in Attachment A. (16) (17) and (18) It would be premature to answer these questions prior to Coalition investigators completing their search for WMD in Iraq, but see also answer to question 19. (19) The Government is confident in the judgment that Iraq possessed a WMD capability in the lead-up to the war. Australian intelligence agencies are continuing to assess the scope and nature of that capability in the light of current investigations. (20) and (21) No doubts were expressed by the intelligence agencies or my department about whether Iraq had WMD capability. (22) This question should be directed to the Minister for Defence, whose department is co-ordinating the Australian contribution. (23) It is not possible to compare the cost directly. The cost of UNMOVIC and IAEA weapons inspectors is paid out of the UN and IAEA budgets respectively. Australia pays an annual assessed contribution to both of these organisations. (24) and (25) Australia believes that international organisations such as UNMOVIC and the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) have a role to play in Iraq. Australia has conveyed this view to the US and UK Governments. However, the circumstances under which these organisations operated before the conflict with Iraq commenced have changed. This has been recognised by the UN Security Council in UNSCR 1483 which “underlines the intention of the Council to revisit their mandates”. The Australian Government favoured the early return of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) to resume its safeguards responsibilities in Iraq in line with Iraq’s Non-Proliferation Treaty safeguards agreement. Australia made its position known in Washington. An IAEA team was despatched to the Iraqi nuclear research centre al-Tuwaitha and commenced inspections on 7 June. Health: Outer Metropolitan Doctors Scheme (Question No. 2132) Ms Hall asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 26 June 2003. In respect of the 75 doctors who are relocating to outer metropolitan areas under the Government’s program, can the Minister provide a list detailing where each of those doctors is relocating from and where each is relocating to. the honourable member’s question: As at 21 July 2003, 87 doctors had been approved to participate in the More Doctors for Outer Metropolitan Areas Measure. Of this number, 64 had been approved to relocate and 23 were undertaking training placements in an outer metropolitan area. Provision of suburb level information for each relocating doctor could enable identification of individual doctors, and this is considered inappropriate for privacy reasons. The following data provides an indication of where the doctors participating in the Measure are located, by State: New South Wales 21 Victoria 29 Queensland 19 South Australia 4 Tasmania4 Western Australia 10 Barton Electorate: Benefits (Question No. 2155) 11 August 2003: (1) What programs have been introduced, continued or renewed by the Minister’s Department in the electoral division of Barton since March 1996 (2) What grants and or benefits have been provided to individuals, businesses and organisations by the Minister’s Department in the electoral division of Barton since 1996.

theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Rockdale City Council 2000-01 $1,895,264 Kogarah Municipal Council 2000-01 $1,034,544 Rockdale City Council 2001-02 $2,017,524 Kogarah Municipal Council 2001-02 $1,095,508 Rockdale City Council 2002-03 $2,044,552 Kogarah Municipal Council 2002-03 $1,152,220 The total amount since 1996 = $20,601,844 The Natural Disaster Risk Management Studies Programme; Rockdale City Council was provided funding in the 2001-02 financial year for a project titled the Rockdale City Flood Hazard Assessment this study seeks to raise peoples flood awareness through various processes so as to ensure that the community can take measures during flood events to protect themselves and their property. Amount: $52,000 Roads to Recovery; Name of Organisation Approved amount over Payments to 30 June4 years 2003 Rockdale City Council $1,340,854 558,688 Kogarah Municipal Council $797,443 531,629 Total amount paid to 30 June 2003 1,080,317 Regional Assistance Programme; Rockdale City Council was provided funding in the 1999-2000 financial year under the Regional Assistance programme for detailed redevelopment planning as Rockdale has experienced the continuing loss of local employment within its area, which has traditionally been in the light industrial and commercial/retail sectors. In the case of light industrial employment, this downturn can be attributed to a general decline in the manufacturing sector of the economy, a shift away from labour intensive manufacturing, and the general relocation of industry to greenfield sites in Western Sydney. In the case of commercial and retail employment, there has been a market shift from traditional local shopping centres to larger regional and sub-regional centres located outside the RCC area. Amount: $28,400 Sydney Airport Noise Insulation Programme. The Sydney Programme commenced in 1994 following the opening of the third runway at the airport. Since that time 146 residences and a church have been voluntarily acquired and some 3,800 residences and over 90 public buildings (schools, preschools, health care facilities and churches) insulated against the effects of aircraft noise at a cost of some $385 million. Commercialising Emerging Technologies (COMET) is designed to increase the commercialisation of innovative products, processes and services, by providing individuals, early-stage growth firms, and spin-off companies with a tailored package of support to improve their potential for successful commercialisation. Total $35,000 Motor Vehicles: Specialist and Enthusiast Vehicle Scheme (Question No. 2174) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 11 August 2003: (1) With respect to the implementation of the changes to the importation and conversion of low volume second hand motor vehicles introduced by the Motor Vehicle Standards Amendment Act 2001, can he advise whether a post implementation review of the new scheme been conducted; if so, by whom, what were its findings and is it publicly available; if a review has been conducted but not publicly released, why not. (2) Has any assessment of the employment implications of the new arrangements been conducted; if not why not; if so, what are the findings. (3) Has the new Act and arrangements achieved the Government’s objectives; if so, what is the evidence to support that conclusion; if not, what are the inadequacies of the Act. (4) Will the Government release the report produced by the Office of Small Business in 2000 on the employment impacts of the move to the Specialist and Enthusiast Vehicle Scheme (SEVS); if not, why not. Mr Ian Macfarlane-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) I understand you have asked a similar question (QON 2173) of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, the Hon John Anderson MP. As he has portfolio responsibility for the Act, I refer this question to him. (2) The Motor Vehicles Standards Amendment Act came into effect on 1 April 2002. Transitional arrangements allowed registered vehicle holders to continue modifying and plating permitted vehicles for the market until 7 May 2003. Given the short period of time the Act has been fully effective, there has been no assessment of the employment implications of the new arrangement. (3) It is too early to determine how successful the Act has been in achieving the Government’s objective given the short period of time it has been in effect. (4) The Government will not be releasing the report. The Office of Small Business was requested by Ministers Anderson and Reith, and Senator Minchin to provide advice on the implications on small business of the SEVS. Mr Reith has previously indicated to Parliament that this advice was for the use of the Ministers only. Motor Vehicles: Private Importation (Question No. 2184) Mrs Irwin asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 11 August 2003 and it was transferred to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services: (1) What restrictions apply to the private importation to Australia by Australian citizens of second hand motor vehicles less than 15 years old and when were they introduced. (2) Were the restrictions imposed as a result of any report or recommendation of a parliamentary committee. (3) Were the restrictions imposed as part of the implementation of an announced Government policy. (4) For what reasons was the ban imposed on privately imported second hand motor vehicles less than 15 years old. (5) Will he allow the importation of vehicles purchased privately overseas before the restrictions were imposed. (1) The Motor Vehicle Standards Regulations 1989 permit the private importation to Australia by Australian citizens of used motor vehicles less than 15 years old under the provisions of regulations 12 to 16 inclusive. In general terms, the regulations provide for: personal imports, where the vehicle has been owned and used continuously for a qualifying period overseas; where the vehicle complied with the Australian Design Rules when it was first manufactured and delivered for use in transport; or where the vehicle is eligible under the Specialist and Enthusiast Vehicle Scheme and the vehicle model is included in the schedule of a registered automotive workshop, in which case the import application must be made by, and approval issued to, the registered automotive workshop. (2) No. (3) Yes. Changes to the import provisions of the Motor Vehicle Standards Regulations 1989 were introduced as part of the Government’s response to the Review of the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989. These changes were announced by Senator Minchin and me on 8 May 2000 and included: abolition of the former low volume scheme for used vehicles after a two year transition period; creation of the Specialist and Enthusiast Vehicle Scheme; removal of provisions allowing the importation of vehicles for dismantling; and extension of the qualifying period for personal imports from 90 days to 12 months. (4) There is no ban on privately imported second hand vehicles. There are restrictions, as noted in (1) above. (5) Yes, if the vehicle can be imported under one of the provisions of the Motor Vehicle Standards Regulations as outlined in (1) above. National Security: Terrorism (Question No. 2203) Did Australia sponsor with the United States and New Zealand a counter terrorism workshop for Pacific Island countries in March 2003; if so, what was the outcome of that workshop. Australia sponsored with the United States and New Zealand a counter terrorism workshop for Pacific Island countries in March 2002. Australia did not sponsor a workshop of this sort in March 2003. The 2002 workshop helped to raise awareness in Pacific Island countries of the nature of the threat of international terrorism and of the role Pacific Island countries have in combating this threat, including through compliance with mandatory United Nations Security Council (UNSC) resolutions and relevant international instruments. Workshop participants agreed that the focus of the regional effort should be on taking practical steps to address the terrorist problem, including the early completion by Pacific Island countries of the reporting requirements of UNSC Resolution 1373.

speaker: Mr Downer
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Funding (Question No. 2252) Mr Murphy asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 13 August 2003: (1) Has the Minister seen the numerous recent media reports calling for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to be allowed to raise advertising revenue to supplement its budget which have been supported by some members of the Government. (2) Will the Minister unequivocally rule out making the policy change or any other policy change which would undermine the independence of the public broadcaster; if not, why not. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) Yes. (2) The Government remains committed to the independence of the ABC as provided for by Parliament under the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983. Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Funding (Question No. 2279) Mr Murphy asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 18 August 2003: Further to the answer to part (3) of question No. 1944 (Hansard, 12 August 2003, page 18177), will he, for the life of this Parliament, rule out amending the Australian Broadcasting Act 1983 in a way which would allow the public broadcaster to raise revenue through commercial advertising on its television and radio networks; if not, why not. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: Yes. Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Funding (Question No. 2280) Mr Murphy asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 18 August 2003: (1) Has the Minister seen the article by the Shadow Minister for Communications, titled “Ads would undermine our ABC” that appeared in The Age newspaper on 14 August 2003. (2) Can he explain how the Government’s policy differs from that expressed in the article. (3) Is the Minister aware that the overwhelming majority of Australians who support the ABC do not want the public broadcaster to be competing for commercial advertising revenue with the commercial media moguls because of the threat to its independence and the ensuing consequences for Australian democracy. (4) Will he make an immediate public statement to the effect that he will not allow the ABC to raise revenue through commercial advertising; if not, why not. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) Yes.
